description: Set the gravity as a vector or float. Gravity is set in units of acceleration. Body force is calculated as the product of the gravity vector and the real mass of an object. As a shorthand, only a single scalar value f may be specified instead. If this is done, gravity is set to (0,0,-f).
notes: Gravity is in units of acceleration (e.g., m/s², ft/s²)
Body force = gravity vector × real mass of object
Shorthand: single scalar f is equivalent to vector (0,0,-f)
Default gravity: (0,0,0) - no gravity unless explicitly set
Positive z-direction is typically upward in PFC convention
Gravity applies to all pieces: balls, clumps, walls (if dynamic)
Can be changed at any time during simulation

examples.description: Set gravity to 9.81 m/s² downward (equivalent to (0,0,-9.81))
Explicitly set gravity vector to 9.81 m/s² downward
Set gravity to 10 m/s² downward (rounded for simplicity)
Set gravity in negative y-direction (non-standard orientation)
Set gravity with both x and z components (e.g., inclined system)

examples.command:
model domain extent -10 10
ball generate number 1000 radius 0.5
model gravity 9.81
model cycle 5000
examples.description: Setup domain, generate balls, apply gravity, and cycle
Apply gravity and solve to equilibrium under gravitational loading
Set gravity in ft/s² units (standard gravity in imperial units)

python_sdk_alternative.python_code:
# Set gravity using scalar (shorthand)
itasca.set_gravity(9.81)

# Set gravity using vector
itasca.set_gravity_vector((0, 0, -9.81))

# Get current gravity
grav = itasca.get_gravity()
print(grav)  # Returns vector (x, y, z)
python_sdk_alternative.notes: Python SDK provides itasca.set_gravity(scalar) and itasca.set_gravity_vector(tuple) functions. Use itasca.get_gravity() to retrieve current gravity vector
